abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome was moderately
            satisfactory, and sustainability of the anticipated benefits
            is likely. The project had a substantial impact on
            institutional development. World Bank performance was
            satisfactory, while Borrower performance was unsatisfactory.
            Experience with this project suggests the following lessons:
            1) Financing the continuing work of contract advisors who
            are already advising the government is a questionable
            practice, since it makes it extremely difficult for the Bank
            to fulfill its quality control function. Bank funding should
            primarily support activities when the Bank can contribute to
            the success of these activities, if in no other way than by
            reviewing the reports and recommendations of the consultant.
            2) The contracts that were negotiated with legal advice from
            advisors financed by the Bank remain confidential documents.
            The Bank should make every effort to get governments to
            agree to make public the basic financial elements of
            agreements and contracts that are negotiated with foreign
            companies. Public review of such contracts is the best way
            to establish transparency and accountability in dealing with
            the exploitation of national resources such as oil. In
            particular, the Bank should only provide technical
            assistance for the negotiating of contracts that are
            intended to become part of the public domain (at least in
            their broad terms).

2280434.trustfund:
TF023875-USAID-ENERGY/ENVIRONMENT STUDY
            IN NIS,TF022620-CANADIAN CTF FOR E. & C.
            EUROPE & THE CIS,TF020855-AUSTRIAN CONSULTANT TRUST FUND
            FOR E & C EUROPE,TF035883-KAZAKSTAN - OIL AND GAS,TF034419-ECA REGION - PETROLUM AND
            PROJECT WORK,TF033097-RUSSIA - ENERGY

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated satisfactory, the
            likelihood of sustainability is high, and the institutional
            development impact is substantial. The lessons address,
            first, the reasons why the project performed successfully:
            The degree of staff continuity was critical, not only
            experience wise, but in that it retained as well, the
            project's institutional memory. Furthermore, it
            strengthened the borrower's ownership of project
            activities, which emphasized the responsibility needed to
            manage the implementation, and operation of the project.
            These activities, if conducted under clear sponsorship,
            minimize the risks of unnecessary, or unsustainable work,
            easing implementation. Secondly, those areas where
            improvement could be made: Regardless of how minimal it may
            appear, administrative efficiency is critical in keeping
            financial obligations against the state budget in track, and
            avoiding inefficiencies, which could be later magnified as
            overall delay factors in the implementation process. In
            addition, implementation was hindered by poor coordination,
            which affected its pace, and project deliverables. A
            proactive, and responsive Bank support is not only needed
            from Headquarters, but from the field office as well, which
            require the full capacity of local staff. However, the
            apparent lack of knowledge, and inexperience of local staff
            about the Bank, precluded covering the full scope of the project.

18218734.trustfund:
TF023875-USAID-ENERGY/ENVIRONMENT STUDY
            IN NIS,TF020855-AUSTRIAN CONSULTANT TRUST FUND
            FOR E & C EUROPE,TF035883-KAZAKSTAN - OIL AND GAS,TF022620-CANADIAN CTF FOR E. & C.
            EUROPE & THE CIS,TF034419-ECA REGION - PETROLUM AND
            PROJECT WORK,TF033097-RUSSIA - ENERGY
18218734.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Financial and private sector development,Rule of law

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objective of the Petroleum
            Technical Assistance Project is to assist Kazakhstan to
            strengthen the capacity of the key petroleum subsector
            agencies to: 1) attract foreign investments into the
            subsector; 2) promote the efficiency and long-term financial
            viability of the petroleum industries; and 3) formulate
            economically sound investment and organizational strategies
            for the integration of domestic primary petroleum
            production, processing, transport, and distribution. The
            project consists of two components: Institutional
            Development, and Project Preparation and Implementation
            Support. The first, has three subcomponents:  1) supporting
            the creation of an effective framework for promoting foreign
            investments in the petroleum subsector by assisting in
            finalizing a petroleum law and formulating a tax code,
            appraising potential investment projects, and structuring
            and negotiating transactions with prospective investors, and
            training local staff;   2) assisting the implementation of a
            program corporatizing and restructuring the petroleum
            industry, and preparing the basis for increased private
            sector participation; and  3) assisting in identifying and
            addressing priority management training needs, and preparing
            and administering training in market-oriented petroleum
            industry operational and commercial practices. The second
            component also has three subcomponents:  1) planned studies
            reviewing the economic feasibility of constructing new
            product pipelines and a crude oil pipeline connecting
            oilfields in the west with the two refineries in the east;
            2) assisting the assessment of regional and domestic market
            potential for natural gas, and the supply and investment
            options for participating in meeting the demand; and  3)
            providing advisory and consultant services to manage the
            day-to-day project's implementation.
